gemini_analysis: {'scam_probability': 100, 'red_flags': ["Unsolicited job offer from an unknown source (implied by 'contacted by a company claiming to be XXXX')", 'Impersonation of a legitimate company (XXXX)', "Vague job description ('completing sets and reviewing albums and singles')", 'Promise of remote work (often used by scammers to broaden reach and avoid physical presence)', 'Victim was convinced to send money to the fraudulent individuals under false pretenses', 'Performing work without receiving compensation as agreed', "Bank denying fraud claim due to 'inconsistencies' (often happens when the victim authorized the transactions, even if under deception)"], 'financial_risk': 'High', 'scam_type': "Job Scam (Impersonation and Advance Fee Variant) - The scammers impersonated a legitimate company to offer a fake job. The primary mechanism of financial loss was convincing the victim to send money (an advance fee) under false pretenses, likely related to 'equipment', 'software', or 'processing fees' for the supposed job.", 'victim_profile': 'The victim appears to be actively seeking remote work opportunities and likely trusted the initial contact and job offer. They were vulnerable to deception due to the promise of legitimate employment and potentially financial need. A lack of awareness regarding common scam tactics, such as never sending money to an employer, made them susceptible to manipulation. The victim also meticulously performed tasks, indicating diligence and belief in the legitimacy of the offer, which scammers exploit.', 'recommendations': ["Never send money to a prospective employer for any reason (e.g., equipment, software, training, 'processing fees', or to 'transfer funds'). Legitimate employers pay you, you don't pay them.", 'Always independently verify job offers directly with the company through official channels (e.g., website contact information, HR department), not using contact details provided by the alleged recruiter.', 'Be highly suspicious of unsolicited job offers, especially those promising easy work for high pay, or those that have vague job descriptions.', 'Research the company thoroughly, looking for any reports of scams or impersonation.', 'Be cautious of communications from generic email addresses (e.g., @gmail.com, @outlook.com) when representing a company.', 'Keep detailed records of all communications and transactions related to the incident.', "For bank claim denials, request a detailed explanation of the 'inconsistencies' found by the bank and seek legal advice or consult with consumer protection agencies regarding appealing the decision.", "Report the incident to the FBI's Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3), the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), and local law enforcement."], 'confidence': 100}

{'scam_probability': 100, 'red_flags': ["Unsolicited job offer or very quick hiring process without typical interviews (implied by 'offered a remote job by someone acting like a big HR person').", 'Fake documentation resembling a real company (Assurant) - easy for scammers to create.', 'Received a check for equipment/initial funds before starting work.', "Insistence on immediate deposit of a check, especially with excuses like 'nature of work environment and the holidays'.", "Extreme pushiness to transfer funds quickly to a 'fake vendor' for remote equipment.", 'The expectation that the victim pays for equipment upfront using funds from a recently deposited check.', "Bank advised to deposit a suspicious check 'to look at it' which is risky advice, as funds become available before the check truly clears.", 'Scammer dictating a specific vendor and payment method for equipment.', 'The check was identified as fraudulent after the funds were transferred by the victim.'], 'financial_risk': 'High', 'scam_type': "Employment Scam / Remote Job Scam combined with a Fake Check Scam and Advance Fee Scam. The 'advance fee' is disguised as payment for equipment, which the victim 'pays' for using funds from a fraudulent check.", 'victim_profile': "The victim is a job seeker, likely vulnerable due to economic pressures ('looking for work in this economy'). They exhibited a degree of diligence by trying to verify accounts and contacting their bank, but ultimately succumbed to pressure tactics and a lack of understanding regarding bank check clearing processes. They are trusting, especially when presented with seemingly legitimate company documentation, and susceptible to urgency. They may not have been fully aware that funds made 'available' by a bank do not mean the check has genuinely cleared.", 'recommendations': ["Never transfer money from a check you've deposited until your bank confirms it has *fully cleared* (which can take days or even weeks, not just when funds become 'available'). Treat any funds from new checks as potentially fraudulent until fully cleared.", 'Legitimate employers do not send checks to new hires for equipment purchases and then instruct them to send money to a third-party vendor. Companies typically purchase and ship equipment directly or reimburse *after* a purchase with official receipts.', "Verify job offers directly with the company through official contact information found on their corporate website, not information provided by the 'recruiter'. Look for multiple layers of verification.", 'Be wary of any job offer that skips traditional interview processes (e.g., video interviews, multiple rounds).', 'Be suspicious of any employer or recruiter who pressures you to act quickly, especially regarding money transfers.', "Educate yourself on how fake check scams work, particularly the difference between 'funds available' and 'check cleared'.", 'If a bank advises depositing a suspicious check, ask clarifying questions about the liability and risks involved before the check fully clears.', "Use caution with payment methods that are irreversible, such as wire transfers or certain payment apps, especially when instructed by a new 'employer'.", 'Report all details to law enforcement (which the victim has done) and relevant government agencies (FBI IC3, FTC, DFPI).'], 'confidence': 100}

{'scam_probability': 95, 'red_flags': ['Unsolicited internship offer via college email, without prior application.', 'No interview process or formal hiring steps (e.g., background check, signing an offer letter).', 'Employer communicates solely through email/messaging, avoiding phone or video calls.', "Separate 'person in charge of materials' introduced to manage equipment purchases.", "Employer sends checks (especially via email/digital images) for 'materials' or equipment.", 'Pressure to deposit a check and immediately use personal funds before the check has fully cleared.', "Insistence on sending money from personal savings to the 'employer' or a designated third party for materials.", "Threat of 'delaying schedule time' to pressure immediate action.", "Disappearance of the 'employer' and 'materials person' once personal funds are transferred.", 'Bank confirms deposited checks were fake.'], 'financial_risk': 'High', 'scam_type': 'Fake Check Scam / Employment Scam (with Advance Fee component). The core mechanism is a fake check, designed to trick the victim into sending real money from their own account before the fraud is discovered.', 'victim_profile': 'A college student seeking a summer internship, likely driven by financial need (to pay student bills). They are potentially less experienced with the intricacies of financial transactions (check clearing times) and may have a higher trust level for communications received through official channels like a college email address. The desire to earn money makes them vulnerable to seemingly legitimate job offers, even with unusual requests.', 'recommendations': ['Be highly skeptical of unsolicited job or internship offers, especially those received without a prior application.', 'Always verify job offers directly with the company using official contact information (from their website, not provided by the sender).', 'Legitimate employers do not send money to employees to purchase equipment or supplies using their personal funds, especially before starting work.', 'Never send money (via wire transfer, gift cards, P2P apps, etc.) to an employer or a third party designated by them for any reason (materials, training, software).', 'Understand how checks clear: Funds are typically made available quickly, but the check itself can take several business days to fully clear. Do not spend money from a deposited check until your bank confirms it has definitively cleared.', 'Be wary of any job that involves depositing checks and then immediately sending a portion of that money elsewhere.', "Report suspicious emails to your college's IT security department.", 'Educate yourself on common scam tactics by consulting resources from the FTC (Federal Trade Commission), FBI, and your bank.', 'If you suspect fraud, cease all communication with the scammer, report it to your bank immediately, and file reports with law enforcement and relevant government agencies (e.g., FTC, FBI Internet Crime Complaint Center - IC3).'], 'confidence': 100}

{'scam_probability': 100, 'red_flags': ['Unsolicited job offer via email (XXXX email in my XXXX account)', "Job requires the victim to purchase materials/pay 'out of pocket'", "Instruction to deposit digital checks from the 'employer' for materials/reimbursement", "Pressure to send money before deposited checks have fully cleared the bank ('Because the wait time was long... I had to pay out of pocket')", "The 'employer' sends 'reimbursement' checks for amounts already paid by the victim, further perpetuating the fake check cycle", 'Communication shifts to another person via text for payments, often a tactic to obscure the main contact', 'Digital checks are provided instead of direct deposit or company funds for purchases', "Scammer disappears immediately once the victim's funds are lost ('he never responded')", 'The checks ultimately bounce, leading to the bank reclaiming funds and the victim losing their own money'], 'financial_risk': 'High', 'scam_type': "Fake Check / Employment Scam (also known as Overpayment Scam). The scam involves depositing a fraudulent check (often a digital image), and then pressuring the victim to send money back or pay for 'materials' before the fake check fully clears the bank. The bank makes the funds 'available' but reverses the deposit once the check is found to be counterfeit, leaving the victim responsible for any money they sent out.", 'victim_profile': "The victim is likely eager for employment or an internship opportunity (indicated by 'internship' and 'over the summer'), making them susceptible to seemingly legitimate job offers. They may lack understanding of how bank check processing works, particularly the difference between 'funds available' and 'funds cleared,' leading them to believe the deposited money is truly theirs to send. This eagerness or lack of financial literacy makes them vulnerable to the scammer's urgency and payment instructions.", 'recommendations': ['Never accept a job offer that asks you to pay money out of your own pocket for materials, training, or software, especially if an employer is supposed to reimburse you with a check.', "Be extremely wary of unsolicited job offers, particularly those sent via generic email addresses or from companies you haven't applied to.", 'Never deposit a check (physical or digital) from an unknown party and then send money back or to a third party. This is a hallmark of a fake check scam.', "Understand that 'funds available' in your bank account does NOT mean a check has fully cleared. It can take weeks for a check to clear, and if it bounces, your bank will withdraw the funds, even if you've already spent or transferred them.", 'Always verify the legitimacy of an employer through independent research (official company website, LinkedIn, legitimate contact numbers) before engaging.', 'If a job requires purchasing equipment or materials, a legitimate employer will typically provide a company credit card, direct vendor payment, or send the equipment directly to you.', 'Report suspicious job offers to the relevant platforms (e.g., job boards) and authorities like the FTC (Federal Trade Commission) or FBI (Internet Crime Complaint Center - IC3).', 'If you have been scammed, immediately contact your bank to report the fraud and attempt to stop any outgoing payments. File a police report, but understand that recovery of funds is often difficult.'], 'confidence': 100}

{'scam_probability': 100, 'red_flags': ['Employer sends a check for you to purchase equipment instead of providing it directly.', "Request to send money via Zelle (or similar instant payment apps) for work-related purchases, especially to an unknown vendor or 'company representative'.", "Funds from a 'company check' are made available quickly, and you're pressured to act before the check has fully cleared (which can take days or weeks).", 'The bank eventually identified the incoming check as fraudulent, leading to the victim being responsible for the disbursed funds.', "Bank acknowledges this is a common scam type ('they see this scam all the time')."], 'financial_risk': 'High', 'scam_type': "Fake Check Scam / Employment Scam. The victim was then instructed to use a portion of these (unclear) funds to purchase equipment via Zelle, a common tactic in fake check scams where the victim effectively sends 'real' money before the 'fake' money deposited into their account bounces.", 'victim_profile': "The victim was actively seeking employment ('avidly trying to get a XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX'), which makes individuals more vulnerable to attractive but fraudulent job offers. The eagerness for a new job likely overrode skepticism about the unusual payment process.", 'recommendations': ["Never trust an employer who sends you a check and then asks you to send money back (or to a third party) for 'equipment' or 'supplies'.", "Always wait for a check to *fully* clear before spending any of the money or sending any funds to others. Research the company thoroughly using independent sources (their official website, LinkedIn, reputable job boards, BBB) and contact them directly using official numbers/emails.', 'Be extremely cautious of jobs that require you to purchase equipment with funds they provide. {'scam_probability': 100, 'red_flags': ['Unsolicited approach for services from an unknown individual claiming to represent a legitimate institution.', 'Insistence on overpaying for services (sending {[AMOUNT]} when only half was suggested as a deposit).', "Insistence on paying with a 'certified cashier's check' - these can be forged and used to build false trust.", "Urgency to cash the check immediately, especially digitally, and the scammer's false assurance that funds were 'deducted from their account the moment I cashed it'.", "The project's scope suddenly changing or being canceled immediately after the check deposit.", "Immediate and urgent request to send back a portion of the funds (the 'overpayment') before the original check has fully cleared.", 'Requests to send money back via irreversible digital payment methods (e.g., Zelle, Cash App, wire transfer).', "Fabricated documents (e.g., 'document supposedly from the school stating the projects Phase XXXX cancellation') to support the scammer's narrative.", 'The original check eventually being identified as fraudulent and reversing, leading to significant financial loss for the victim.', "The scammer going 'dark' and ceasing communication once confronted about the fraudulent check and demands for money.", 'Use of various communication channels (text, email, calls) to create a sense of legitimacy and urgency.'], 'financial_risk': 'High', 'scam_type': "Fake Check Scam / Overpayment Scam. This specific variant is often disguised as a 'Freelance Job' or 'Employment' scam, where the scammer pretends to hire for services, overpays with a fraudulent check, and then demands a portion of the money back before the fake check bounces.", 'victim_profile': "The victim appears to be a freelancer or service provider (e.g., illustrator) seeking legitimate work, making them susceptible to seemingly professional job offers. Key vulnerabilities include: 
- **Trusting Nature:** Believed the legitimacy of the offer and the 'certified cashier's check'. 
- **Lack of Awareness of Banking Hold Periods:** Did not understand that 'funds available' does not mean a check has fully cleared, a common misconception that scammers exploit. 
- **Responsiveness to Urgency:** Complied quickly with requests to send money back, driven by the scammer's insistence on immediate action. 
- **Focus on the 'Work':** Engaged in the project details, which distracted from scrutinizing the financial transaction methods.", 'recommendations': ['**Never Send Money Back:** If you receive a check for more than the agreed amount, return it and request a new check for the correct sum. Never send money back from an overpayment.', "**Wait for Checks to Fully Clear:** Do not spend, transfer, or send money based on funds showing as 'available' in your account. Real check clearing can take 5-10 business days, or even longer for international or suspicious checks.", '**Verify Employment/Client Legitimacy:** Independently verify the client or employer by contacting the organization directly using publicly available contact information (not contact info provided by the potential scammer).', '**Be Wary of Unsolicited Offers:** Exercise extreme caution with job offers or requests for services that come out of the blue, especially if they involve advance payments.', '**Avoid Irreversible Payment Methods:** For new clients or large transactions, avoid using digital cash apps (e.g., Zelle, Cash App) or wire transfers for receiving or sending funds, as these transactions are often irreversible.', "**Understand Your Bank's Policies:** Be aware that banks typically hold the account holder responsible for depositing fraudulent checks, even if you were a victim of a scam.", "**Report the Scam:** File a report with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3), and local law enforcement. Also inform the impersonated 'school' of the scam.", '**Monitor Credit:** Since personal information (name, address, bank, phone) was shared, monitor your credit report for any signs of identity theft.'], 'confidence': 100}

{'scam_probability': 100, 'red_flags': ["Unsolicited job offer with unusually high pay for minimal work (implied by 'get [AMOUNT] per week' for a simple task).", "Receiving a check in the mail as part of the 'job' process, which is a common tactic in fake check scams.", 'The check amount is likely more than expected or intended, requiring the victim to send back a portion of the funds.', "Pressure to act quickly ('needs to go today') to prevent the victim from investigating or questioning the legitimacy.", 'Instructions to deposit a check and then immediately send money via an irreversible method (money order, overnight mail) *before* the deposited check has fully cleared.', "The bank states they 'cannot credit back' the funds, which unequivocally confirms the deposited check was fraudulent and the victim is responsible for the loss."], 'financial_risk': 'High', 'scam_type': "Fake Check Scam / Advance Fee Scam. This is a classic fake check scam, often disguised as a work-from-home job, personal assistant, or mystery shopper role. The victim is instructed to deposit a fraudulent check (often for an 'overpayment' or 'start-up funds') and then send a portion of that money via an untraceable method (like money order or wire transfer) to the scammer or a 'third party' before the fake check bounces. The victim ends up losing the money they sent and is liable for the full amount of the bad check to their bank.", 'victim_profile': "The victim is currently unemployed and actively seeking opportunities to earn 'extra money,' making them financially vulnerable and eager to believe in a seemingly easy income source. Their statement, 'I thought that its gon na be nice to make an extra money,' indicates a susceptibility to 'too good to be true' offers. They likely lack awareness regarding how bank checks clear, the duration of bank holds, and the common mechanics of fake check scams, making them susceptible to pressure tactics and the promise of quick funds.", 'recommendations': ["Never send money back to someone who sent you a check, especially if it's for an amount larger than expected. This is a hallmark of fake check scams.", 'Always wait for a check to fully clear with your bank before spending or transferring any funds. A deposit showing up in your account does NOT mean the check has cleared; it can take weeks for a check to clear the issuing bank.', "Be highly suspicious of job offers that require you to deposit a check and then immediately send money via an irreversible method (e.g., money order, wire transfer, gift cards) to a third party or back to the 'employer'.", "Be wary of job offers that seem 'too good to be true,' promise high pay for little effort, or require you to use your personal bank account for company transactions.", 'Verify any job offer directly with the company through official contact information found independently (e.g., company website), not information provided by the person offering the job.', 'Educate yourself about common scam types, particularly fake check scams, which are prevalent in online job searches.', "Report the scam to relevant authorities, including the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the FBI's Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3), and your local police department."], 'confidence': 100}

{'scam_probability': 100, 'red_flags': ["Bait-and-switch: Original job application for a school position led to an email for a different 'partner' and a different 'XXXX XXXX job'.", "Vague and unusual job duties: 'Running personal errands' and handling 'donations ranging from foster care to invoices to colleagues' is highly suspicious for a personal assistant role, especially for a school partner.", 'Quick hiring process: No mention of a formal interview, immediate start date after exchanging information.', "Request to handle company funds through personal bank account: The 'employer' sent a check for purchases and money orders, asking the victim to use their personal bank account for these transactions.", "Overpayment scenario: The victim was instructed to make purchases and send a portion of the money (via money order) to others, implying the initial check covered these amounts plus the victim's 'pay'.", 'Use of irreversible payment methods: Requesting funds to be sent via money orders, which are difficult to trace and recover once sent.', "Bounced check: The definitive indicator that the funds provided by the 'employer' were fraudulent.", "Employer's contact information discrepancy: The school district verified they did not host the specific job listing, confirming it was fake.", "Prevalence of similar scams: Victim's research found 'plenty' of similar job listings with the same suspicious format.", "Bank representative's comment: The statement 'this was a common thing' happening indicates it's a known scam pattern."], 'financial_risk': 'High', 'scam_type': 'Fake Check Scam (specifically a Personal Assistant / Mystery Shopper variant). This scam involves sending a fraudulent check to the victim, instructing them to deposit it, keep a portion as payment, and then send the remainder (often via irreversible methods like money orders or wire transfers) to a third party before the initial check ultimately bounces, leaving the victim responsible for the entire amount.', 'victim_profile': 'The victim is highly vulnerable due to being recently homeless and unemployed, making them desperate for legitimate work and a steady income. A check can take days or weeks to officially bounce, and the depositor is ultimately responsible for any fraudulent checks.', 'Consider seeking financial counseling to help manage the current debt and rebuild financial stability, given the previous hardship.'], 'confidence': 100}

{'scam_probability': 100, 'red_flags': ['Unsolicited job offer received via email.', 'Very quick hiring process: application, interview, and job offer all within a few days.', "Initial feeling that the job was 'too good to be true'.", 'Employer sent checks to the victim to purchase work equipment and software.', "Instruction to deposit checks and then immediately send funds (via Zelle) to a 'vendor' for equipment purchase.", "Checks eventually bounced, leading to the victim's own funds being used.", 'Use of Zelle for business-related transactions (Zelle is primarily for personal transfers between known individuals).', "The 'employer' (CardConnect hiring department employees) instructed personal financial transactions.", "The 'employer' gave the 'run around' when asked for reimbursement, indicating evasion and lack of accountability.", 'Local police precinct deemed the entire situation as fraud and is investigating.'], 'financial_risk': 'High', 'scam_type': "This is a classic 'Fake Check / Job Scam' combined with elements of an 'Advance Fee Scam' and potentially a 'Money Mule Scam'. The victim was sent fraudulent checks (fake check scam) under the guise of employment (job scam). They were then instructed to deposit these checks and immediately send a portion of the funds to a supposed 'vendor' for equipment via an irreversible method like Zelle. When the fake checks inevitably bounced, the victim was left responsible for the funds they had already sent, resulting in a direct financial loss (advance fee component). The 'vendor' to whom the money was sent could be another victim, a money mule, or an accomplice of the scammers.", 'victim_profile': "The victim was unemployed and actively seeking job opportunities, making them highly vulnerable to attractive-looking job offers. They exhibited trust in the legitimacy of the email, the interview process, and the perceived employer, especially given their long-standing relationship with their bank. They likely felt pressure to comply with instructions from their new 'employer' to secure their position, and may have been unaware of how fake checks work and the immediate liability for deposited funds. This eagerness to start a new job and potential lack of awareness regarding financial scam tactics made them an ideal target.", 'recommendations': ["Never accept or deposit checks from a new employer for the purpose of purchasing equipment, software, or any supplies. Legitimate companies either provide equipment directly, use company credit cards, or reimburse through payroll after purchases are made with the employee's own funds (but never upfront for equipment the company is supposed to provide).", "Never send money (especially via irreversible methods like Zelle, wire transfers, or gift cards) to any third party or 'vendor' at the direction of a new employer. This is a hallmark of a scam.", 'Be highly suspicious of unsolicited job offers, particularly those promising quick hiring processes, remote work, and high pay for minimal requirements.', "Always independently verify the legitimacy of a company and job opening. You are responsible for any bounced checks.", 'Continue cooperating fully with local law enforcement and your bank (Citizens Bank) in their investigations. Provide all requested documentation and information.', 'Monitor your credit reports and bank statements closely for any unusual or unauthorized activity, as your personal information may have been compromised during the scam.', "File additional reports with federal agencies such as the FBI's Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3.gov) if you haven't already, and retain all communication with the scammers.", 'Educate yourself on common job scam tactics to prevent future victimization.'], 'confidence': 100}
